column8:
Sir Jack Brabham & BT19 T-shirt.

This t-shirt design admires the Formula One triple World Champion, Sir Jack Brabham.
Sir Jack wasn't just a great F1 driver, he was also mechanically and technically gifted - He not only won the F1 World Championship three times, but he won it in a car bearing his own name - something that will probably never be repeated...imagine Lewis Hamilton winning a world championship for the Hamilton-Mercedes Team!

Brabham initially raced for Cooper Car Company (He won two World Championships for Cooper in 1959 & 1960), but also owned his own car dealership which sold "upgraded" road cars with the engineering help of his friend Ron Tauranac.
Sir Jack & Ron had dreamt of creating their own racing cars, and in the mid 60's when Cooper started to lose their form, they started Brabham Racing Organisation.

It started out like most other small teams in F1 without much success, but in 1966 a new 3-litre formula was created for Formula One. The new engines under development by other suppliers all had at least 12 cylinders and proved difficult to develop.

Brabham took a different approach and asked Repco to develop a 3-litre V8 for them. Although it was less powerful than their competitor's 12 cylinder powerplants, the Repco was light and more importantly, reliable.

On July 3rd, 1966, Jack won the French Grand Prix in the Brabham BT19. He went on to win the next four races, the British, Dutch & German Grands Prix and secured the 1966 World Championship in his own car.

A key part of the art work for this t-shirt design was produced by Yukio Miyamoto and is endorsed by Sir Jack Brabham himself.  It is a detailed Adobe Illustrator drawing with a profile of Jack in the background from his earlier days (around 1960) along with his signature.
The t-shirt features printing on the front and the back and is a special edition t-shirt.
The cost of this t-shirt design is £40. 7.5% of the gross sale price of each shirt is donated to Sir jack Brabham's  Charity, Kidney Health Australia.
column21: Among other great achievements, Jack Brabham was also the first man to win a Formula One world championship in a car of his own construction, which I think is amazing and something which will probably never be repeated. Admire him with this special t shirt from weadmire.net.

column8:
Koi were developed from the common carp in Japan in the 1820s, and are still popular there because they are a symbol of love and friendship. A variety of colours and colour patterns have since been developed.

The word 'Koi' simply means 'carp' in Japanese.
column21: A t-shirt designed in admiration of the Koi Carp, a monarch among fish. From weadmire.net.

column8:
Leigh Bowery (26 March 1961 - 31 December 1994) was an Australian performance artist, club promoter, actor, pop star, model and fashion designer, based in London. Bowery is considered one of the more influential figures in the 1980s and 1990s London and New York art and fashion circles influencing a generation of artists and designers. 
This design celebrates the many faces of an extraordinary artist.
column21: A t-shirt celebrating the extraordinary Leigh Bowery, the Australian artist and performer (among many other things). From We Admire.net

column8: The modern artist Man Ray is known as a significant contributor to the Dada and surrealist movements and most famous for his avant-garde photography, however it's his ideas on the 'Machine' in the early 20th Century that inspired me to design the Man Ray Apple t-shirt.  Man Ray used the machine as a means to express the dilemmas of modern day life and in one example of his work he substituted a screw for a stem in an apple.  By inserted a part of the machine into the Edenic fruit that represents good and evil and the fall of man, Man Ray makes us ask ourselves... "Does the fall stem from the machine, or does man's invention of the machine reenact the fall?" (Man Ray and the Machine, by Barbara Zabel © 1989 Smithsonian American Art Museum.)
column21: The modern artist Man Ray is known as a significant contributor to the Dada and surrealist movements and most famous for his avant-garde photography, however it's his ideas on the 'Machine' in the early 20th Century that inspired me to design the Man Ray Apple t-shirt.
